abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Finance Recovery
            Credit's outcome is rated as satisfactory,
            sustainability as likely, institutional development impact
            as modest, Bank performance as satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance as satisfactory. The main exogenous factor which
            affected the implementation and therefore the outcome of
            this operation is the shortage of external financing during
            the period of 2002 and 2001, which resulted in episodes of
            cash rationing and diverted attention away from structural
            reform implementation. On the one hand, the medium-term
            policy framework supported by such operations need to be as
            comprehensive as possible. On the other hand, evaluation of
            past adjustment operations for Niger and other countries has
            shown that an abundance of conditionalities have been a
            cause of unsatisfactory outcomes. The lesson learned is that
            in an emergency or recovery environment, adjustment support
            should be anchored in a medium-term framework. There may be
            occasions where the Bank must take calculated risk in
            providing a timely response to client need, but this can
            only occur on the basis of close work with the IMF
            beforehand and with Fund endorsement. Even when time does
            not permit the formulation of a parallel TA operation, there
            is potential for capacity building activities through the
            client's commitment of some of his own resources to
            that purpose, even if only to jump start activities in
            anticipation of subsequent external support.
